title: Donald Trump mistakenly said that Hillary Clinton wanted to go to a one-time plan for health care.
text: Donald Trump called the Affordable Care Act a "disaster" that he wanted to cancel and that Hillary Clinton would make health care worse. Trump said during the presidential debate at the University of Washington in St. Louis on 9 October. "Something similar to Canada. And if you ever notice Canadians -- when they need a big operation when something happens, they come to the United States in many cases because their system is too slow, it's catastrophic in certain ways. But she wants to go to a single motive, which means the government controls everything. Does Clinton want to move the United States into a single payment system for health care? The Clinton Health Care Plan to transform Obama's care into a one-time programme would make it, like the Medical Care Programme, a federal health insurance programme run by the federal government. The Government provides health care to all under a one-time system. At present, Obama ' s welfare promotes the policies of private insurance companies. Some Democrats - including Barack Obama at one time - have been pushed into a one-time system. However, there was insufficient support for this, and eventually Congress approved a plan that allows different insurance schemes to be put in place in "market places" by individual states and the federal government. During the discussion of the Vice-President, Tramp Goff. Mike Pines made a similar allegation that Clinton and Tim Kane "wanted to expand (Obamakari) into a single payment program." Here is exactly what she said on her website to her campaign about a general option: "Defens and expand the law on affordable care, which covers 20 million people. Hilary will stand up to Republican-led attacks on this historic law - building on his success in realizing the promise of affordable health care for more people and making the "general option" possible. It will also support allowing people over 55 to buy medical care." So Clinton wants a general option, but she calls for adding the general option to the current options. Clinton has consistently said, including during the October 9 debate, that it wants to protect Obama's care from being abolished by Republicans. It called for its expansion to include tax exemptions, the elimination of charges imposed by off-line hospitals on many schemes, and the reduction of prescription drugs by lifting the ban on the federal Government from negotiating the prices of medicines and allowing Americans to neglect their drugs from cheaper countries.
